mrs. morris: {Enter Mrs. Morris}

mink: [Enter Mink, dirty and sweaty. She starts collecting tools from around the house and putting them in a sack.]

mrs. morris: Heavens, Mink, what’s going on?

mink: The most exciting game ever!

mrs. morris: Catch your breath.

mink: Can I take these things, Mom?

mrs. morris: Yes, just don’t dent them. What’s the name of the game?

mink: Invasion! All the kids are playing it!
[Mink slams the door and runs outside.]
[Enter Mink and other kids]
[Mink drops the tool in the semi circle and starts directing the kids.]
Okay, we’ll need this, and this, and this. No no, don’t do that, dummy, do this! Like that, see?
Go away, Joe!
Well, you can’t.
You’d just make fun of us and ruin the invasion.
No. we know you. You’re too old. Go away or we’ll kick you.

joe: I’m not that old, I just turned twelve!

mink: Too! Old! Go away!!

joe: [Joe walks away, but keeps looking back.]

mrs. morris: [Mrs. Morris is looking down at Mink and Anna through a window.]

mink: [Mink is listening to a bush, Drill is not there]
What do we put here?
[Mink waits for an answer]
Triangle.

anna: How do you spell tri- tri-angle?

mink: T-r-i…Oh just spell it yourself!

mrs. morris: T-r-i-a-n-g-l-e.
Of course, dear. Mink, come in for lunch, will you?

mink: Aww, but Mom!

mrs. morris: Now, Mink. Come on!
[Exit Mrs. Morris.]

mink: [to Drill who is now in the bush]: I have to head to lunch, I’ll be right back.

drill: Hurry. Zero hour is at five o’clock.

stage: [Mrs. Morris puts lunch in front of Mink, who eats it quickly]

mrs. morris: Slow down, Mink. Hot soup will be ready in a minute.

mink: Hurry, Mom! This is a matter of life and death; Drill’s waiting for me!

mrs. morris: {Sets bowl of soup in front of Mink}: Who’s Drill? A new boy in the neighborhood?

mink: Oh, he’s new all right. You don’t know him.

mrs. morris: Which boy is he? Is he shy?

mink: I guess, in a way. And I’m not telling you. You’ll poke fun. {checks time, springs up} Gosh, Mom, I got to run if we want to have the Invasion!

mrs. morris: I’m sorry, who’s invading what?

mink: Martians are invading Earth. Well, not exactly Martians. They’re– I don’t know. From up. {points up}

mrs. morris: [Mrs. Morris takes an indulgent tone from here on out]
Mrs. Morris, jokingly: Uh huh. {checks Mink’s forehead}

mink: You’re laughing! You just want to kill Drill and everyone else.

mrs. morris: I promise, I won’t. Is Drill a Martian?

mink: He’s– well– I’m not sure. Maybe. He’s from Jupiter or Saturn or somewhere. Anyways, He’s had a difficult time; he can’t figure out how to attack Earth.

mrs. morris: Well, I can imagine. We’re pretty strong.

mink: Yeah, he said that in order to make a good fight, you need to surprise people. And– and you need to get help from your enemy. That’s how you win.

mrs. morris: Oh, of course.

mink: And they were upset because they didn’t know how to get through. Until one day, they thought of children!

mrs. morris: Well! Isn't that something!

mink: And how grownups are always so busy, and they never look under rose bushes or on lawns!

mrs. morris: Only for snails and fungus

mink: And then there’s something about– dimin-shuns.

mrs. morris: Dimensions?

mink: Yeah, four of them! And also something about kids under nine, and imagination. It’s real funny to hear Drill talk.

mrs. morris: I imagine it is. Well, you’d better hurry along now, if you and Drill want to have your Invasion before your supper bath.

mink: Aw, mom, do I have to take a bath? Drill says I won’t have to take baths.

mrs. morris: Oh, did he now?

mink: Mhm. He told all the kids that. No more baths, and staying up until ten o’clock, and seeing two television shows on Saturday instead of one!

mrs. morris: Well, Drill better mind his manners–

mink: {interrupts, goes to the door} We’re having trouble with the older kids. They’re growing up, and they’re worse than the parents. They just poke fun at us for believing in Drill, and you’d think they’d know better ‘cause they were little only a couple of years ago. I hate them the worst. We’ll kill them first.

mrs. morris: {amusedly} Your father and I last, I hope?

mink: Y’know, Drill says you’re dangerous. ‘Cause you don’t believe in Martians. That’s why they’re letting us run the whole world. Well, not just us, but the kids over in the next block, too. I might be queen. {opens door} Mom?

mrs. morris: Yes?

mink: What’s lodge-ick?

mrs. morris: Logic? Well, it means to know what things are and aren’t true.

mink: He mentioned that. And what’s- im-presh-on-able?

mrs. morris: Well- {laughs gently} I suppose it means to be a child, dear.

mink: Thanks for lunch, Mom! And I’ll be sure you won’t get hurt much, really!
{Exit Mink, slamming door behind her}

mrs. morris: Well, thanks.
(Mrs. Morris answers)
Hello Helen!

helen: Hello, Mary. How are things in New York?

mrs. morris: Fine. How are things in Scranton? You look tired.

helen: So do you. It’s the children, always underfoot.

mrs. morris: (Sigh) My Mink too, with this “super-invasion”.

helen: Oh, are your kids playing that too?

mrs. morris: Lord yes. Were we this bad when we were kids?

helen: Worse. I don't know how my parents put up with me. My boy Tim’s got a crush on some guy named–Drill, I think it was.

mrs. morris: Must be a new password. Mink likes him too.

helen: Didn’t know it had got as far as New York. Word of mouth, I imagine. I talked to Josephine in Boston and she said her kids are wild on this new game. It’s sweeping the nation.

mink: [Enter Mink]

mrs. morris: How are things going?

mink: Almost finished.

mrs. morris: Swell. What's that?

mink: A yoyo. Watch.
(Mink flings the yoyo down the string.)

mrs. morris: That just disappeared! Do that again.

mink: Can’t. Zero hour is five-o-clock.
[Mink leaves excitedly to go outside to Anna and the other kids]

helen: Huh, Tim brought one of those yo-yos this morning, but when I got curious he wouldn’t show it to me. When I tried to work it, finally, it wouldn’t work.

mink: You’re not impressionable.

mrs. morris: Nevermind. Just something I thought of.

stage: {Shouts/loud noise from outside, Anna starts crying}

mrs. morris: I’d better run. I’ll talk to you later, Helen.

mink: (Mink is ordering around the kids. Anna is crying.)

mrs. morris: [Enter Mrs. Morris]
Mink, why is Anna crying?

mink: ‘cause she’s a scarebaby. We wouldn’t let her play, I think she’s getting too old. I guess she grew up all of a sudden.

mrs. morris: Nonsense. Give me a civil answer, young lady, or inside you come.

mink: I can’t quit now, it’s almost time. I’ll be good, I’m sorry.

mrs. morris: Did you hit Anna?

mink: No, honest. You ask her. It was something– well, she’s just a scaredy pants.

mrs. morris: …Alright.

mink: to the kids: There and there.

mrs. morris: What’s wrong?

mink: Drill’s stuck halfway. If we could get him all the way through it would be easier. Then all the others could come through after him.

mrs. morris: Can I help in any way?

mink: No, thanks. I'll fix it.

mrs. morris: All right, I’ll call you for your bath in half an hour.
[Mrs. Morris goes back inside]

sounds: A clock somewhere in the house: Five-o-clock. Five-o-clock. Five-o-clock. (chime rings 5 times)

mrs. morris: chuckling uneasily: Zero hour.

mr. morris: (Mr. Morris gets out of his car and walks towards the house. He stops for a moment to watch Mink and the kids play. He walks inside.)

mrs. morris: {Enter Mrs. Morris, sitting}
Oh, hello, Henry.

mr. morris: Swell day. Makes you glad to be alive.

mrs. morris: I don’t know.
{Mrs. Morris stands up suddenly.}
Those children haven’t been doing anything dangerous, have they?

mr. morris: Heck no, I looked. Nothing but pipes and hammers.

mrs. morris: You’d better go tell them to quit, it’s after five. Tell them… Tell them to put off their invasion until tomorrow.
{Mrs. Morris laughs nervously}

mr. morris: What are they up to? I’d better go lo–

mrs. morris: UP THIS WAY! IN THE ATTIC, THAT’S WHERE IT IS!
{Mrs. Morris pulls Mr. Morris upstairs to the attic}

mr. morris: It’s not in the attic, It’s outside!

mrs. morris: No, no, I’ll show you, Henry, I’ll show you!

{Mrs. Morris is gasping and wheezing; Mr. Morris is incredulous and confused. Mrs. Morris pulls Mr. Morris into the attic and they tumble in. Mrs. Morris slams the door and locks it, then throws the key away. More explosions in the distance.}
{shaking and sobbing against the door} There, There. We’re safe until tonight. Maybe– maybe we can sneak out, maybe we can escape–

mr. morris: ARE YOU CRAZY? WHY’D YOU THROW THAT KEY AWAY??

mrs. morris: Yes yes, I’m crazy, just– just please, stay here with me.

mr. morris: I’m not sure how in hell I'd get out!

mrs. morris: Quiet, they’ll hear us, oh god, they’ll find  us soon!

sounds: {Buzzing and clattering noises continue/grow louder also lots of footsteps}

mr. morris: Who’s tramping around down there? Who’s there?

mrs. morris: Nononononono, hush, please be quiet!

mink: from down below: Mom? Dad?
Mom, Dad, where are you?
Mom! Dad!
{Mink opens the door and peers inside, tall blue shadows are behind her}
Peekaboo!
